interface.name: wl_tablet_manager

description.summary: controller object for graphic tablet devices

interface.description: An object that provides access to the graphics tablets available on this system.

entry.name: external
entry.summary: The tablet is an external tablet, such as an Intuos

entry.name: internal
entry.summary: The tablet is a built-in tablet, usually in a laptop

entry.name: display
entry.summary: The tablet is a display tablet, such as a Cintiq

arg.name: id
arg.summary: the newly added graphics tablet

arg.name: name
arg.summary: the device name

arg.name: vid
arg.summary: vendor id

arg.name: pid
arg.summary: product id

event.name: tool_added

description.summary: a new tool has been used with a tablet

event.description: This event is sent whenever a tool that has not previously been used with a tablet comes into use. This provides the information about the tool, along with a wl_tablet_tool object that is unique to this tool. If the tablet the tool is being used with does not report the serial numbers for each tool, then the uniqueness of each tool object cannot be guaranteed. On tablets where the serial number is not reported, the "tool_serial" argument will always be 0.

arg.name: id
arg.summary: the newly added tablet tool

arg.name: tablet
arg.summary: The tablet that the tool was seen with

arg.name: tool_type
arg.summary: the physical tool type

arg.name: tool_serial
arg.summary: the unique serial number of the tool

arg.name: extra_axes
arg.summary: A bitfield of all of the extra axes the tablet supports

event.name: seat

description.summary: the seat associated with the tablet manager

event.description: For various functions with the weston desktop shell, a input seat of some sort is required. Because tablets are not officially part of the wayland protocol yet, we can't grab the tablet manager resource from the seat like we would a pointer or a touchscreen. Therefore, an event must be sent that contains a pointer to the wl_seat object that the client is using that is associated with the tablet manager.

arg.name: seat
arg.summary: The wl_seat object for the tablet manager

interface.name: wl_tablet_tool
interface.description:
An unique object that represents a physical tool that has been, or is currently in use with a tablet connected to the system. Each wl_tablet_tool object stays valid until the client releases it, and the compositor will always reuse the wl_tablet_tool object (if it still exists) to indicate that the object's respective physical tool has come into proximity of a tablet again.
It should be noted that each wl_tablet_tool object's uniqueness depends on the tablet's ability to report serial numbers. If the tablet doesn't support this capability, then the tool cannot be guaranteed to be unique.

enum.name: type
enum.description: Describes the physical type of a tool.

enum.name: axis_flag

description.summary: a group of additional axes for a tablet

enum.description: Describes a group of additional axes on a tablet.

event.name: removed
event.description: This event is sent when the tool is removed from the system. The client should not expect the resource it currently has associated with the tool to be used again if the tool comes back into proximity later.

request.name: release

description.summary: release the memory for the tool object

request.description: This destroys the client's resource for this tool object. If the tool comes back into proximity, a new resource will be created for the client and associated with the tool.

interface.name: wl_tablet
interface.description:
The wl_tablet interface represents one drawing tablet device.
The wl_tablet interface generates axis events, enter, and leave events for the surfaces that the tool is held over and button events for the buttons on a tablet tool.

enum.name: button_state
enum.description: Describes the physical state of a button which provoked the button event

event.name: proximity_in
event.description:
Notification that this tablet's tool is focused on a certain surface.
This event can be received when the tool has moved from one surface to another, or when the tool has come back into proximity.

arg.name: time
arg.summary: The time of the event with millisecond granularity

arg.name: tool
arg.summary: The tool that came into proximity

arg.name: surface
arg.summary: The current surface the tablet tool is over

event.name: proximity_out
event.description:
Notification that this tablet's tool has either left proximity, or is no longer focused on a certain surface.
In addition, when the tablet tool leaves proximity of the tablet, a set of button release events will be sent for each button that was held down on the tablet. If the tool stays within proximity of the tablet, but the focus changes from one surface to another, a button release event will not be sent until the button is actually released or the tool leaves the proximity of the tablet.

arg.name: time
arg.summary: The time of the event with millisecond granularity

event.name: motion
event.description: Sent whenever a tablet tool moves.

arg.name: time
arg.summary: The time of the event with millisecond granularity

arg.name: x
arg.summary: surface-relative x coordinate

arg.name: y
arg.summary: surface-relative y coordinate

event.name: down
event.description: Sent whenever the tablet tool comes in contact with the surface of the tablet. If the tablet tool moves out of a region while in contact with the surface of the tablet, the client owning said region will receive a wl_tablet::up event, followed by a wl_tablet::proximity_out event and a wl_tablet::frame event.

arg.name: time
arg.summary: The time of the event with millisecond granularity

event.name: up

description.summary: tablet tool is no longer making contact

event.description: Sent whenever the tablet tool stops making contact with the surface of the tablet, or when the tablet tool moves off of a surface while it was making contact with the tablet's surface.

arg.name: time
arg.summary: The time of the event with millisecond granularity

event.name: pressure
event.description: Sent whenever the pressure axis on a tool changes. The value of this event is normalized to a value between 0 and 65535.

arg.name: time
arg.summary: The time of the event with millisecond granularity

arg.name: pressure
arg.summary: The current pressure value

event.name: distance
event.description: Sent whenever the distance axis on a tool changes. The value of this event is normalized to a value between 0 and 65535.

arg.name: time
arg.summary: The time of the event with millisecond granularity

arg.name: distance
arg.summary: The current distance value

event.name: tilt
event.description: Sent whenever one or both of the tilt axes on a tool change. Each tilt value is normalized between -65535 and 65535.

arg.name: time
arg.summary: The time of the event with millisecond granularity

arg.name: tilt_x
arg.summary: The current value of the X tilt axis

arg.name: tilt_y
arg.summary: The current value of the Y tilt axis

event.name: button
event.description: Sent whenever a button on the stylus is pressed or released.

arg.name: time
arg.summary: The time of the event with millisecond granularity

arg.name: button
arg.summary: The button whose state has changed

arg.name: state
arg.summary: Whether the button was pressed or released

event.name: frame
event.description: Marks the end of a series of axis updates from the tablet. Motion, pressure, distance, and tilt events are all axis events. Axis updates are received from drawing tablets at the same time, so the frame event may be used to separate each individual series of axis updates.

event.name: removed
event.description: Sent when the tablet has been removed from the system. The behavior of the wl_tablet_tool objects afterwards depends on the type of the tablet. For tablets where serial numbers are reported, the tools will be kept in memory until there are no other tablets which support serial numbers connected to the system. If the tool object is one that lacks a serial number because it originated from a tablet where serial numbers are not reported, then it will be destroyed if the tablet it belongs to is destroyed.

request.name: set_cursor
request.description:
Sets the surface of the pointer used for the tablet's tool object. This surface is only shown when the tool is in proximity of the tablet. If the surface is NULL, the pointer image is hidden completely.
The parameters hotspot_x and hotspot_y define the position of the pointer surface relative to the pointer location. Its top-left corner is always at (x, y) - (hotspot_x, hotspot_y), where (x, y) are the coordinates of the pointer location, in surface local coordinates.
On surface.attach requests to the pointer surface, hotspot_x and hotspot_y are decremented by the x and y parameters passed to the request. Attach must be confirmed by wl_surface.commit as usual.
The hotspot can also be updated by passing the currently set pointer surface to this request with new values for hotspot_x and hotspot_y.
The current and pending input regions of the wl_surface are cleared, and wl_surface.set_input_region is ignored until the wl_surface is no longer used as the cursor. When the use as a cursor ends, the current and pending input regions become undefined, and the wl_surface is unmapped.

arg.name: serial
arg.summary: serial of the enter event

arg.name: hotspot_x
arg.summary: x coordinate in surface-relative coordinates

arg.name: hotspot_y
arg.summary: y coordinate in surface-relative coordinates
